name: Foundation of the Maurya Empire
impact: End of Nanda dynasty and birth of the first pan-Indian empire
facts: Chandragupta overthrew Dhanananda with the help of Chanakya

name: Alexander’s Retreat and Mauryan Expansion
parties: Chandragupta Maurya vs Greek Satraps (Seleucus Nicator later)
impact: Chandragupta expanded westward post Alexander's exit
facts: Mauryas later defeated Seleucus and married his daughter

name: Battle with Seleucus I Nicator
impact: Mauryan Empire gained territories in modern-day Afghanistan and Pakistan
facts: A marriage alliance was formed after the battle

name: Appointment of Megasthenes as Ambassador
impact: Megasthenes wrote ‘Indica’, the earliest Western account of India
facts: Indica gives insights into Mauryan administration

name: Ashoka Becomes Emperor
impact: Maurya Empire entered its most expansive and influential phase
facts: Ashoka ruled for nearly 40 years and promoted Buddhism

name: Kalinga War
impact: Ashoka embraced Buddhism after witnessing mass death
facts: More than 100,000 were killed

name: Ashoka’s Dharma Edicts (Major Rock Edict I)
impact: First instance of ethical governance through inscriptions
facts: Ashoka’s edicts were written in Prakrit using Brahmi script

name: Third Buddhist Council
impact: Purified the Buddhist Sangha; sent missionaries abroad
facts: Buddhism spread to Sri Lanka and Central Asia

name: Decline Begins after Ashoka
parties: Dasharatha, Samprati and later weak rulers
impact: Loss of western territories and central control
facts: The empire split into smaller kingdoms by 180 BCE

name: Foundation of the Gupta Empire
impact: Established Gupta rule and started the Classical Age of India
facts: Started the Gupta calendar era in 320 CE

name: Samudragupta's Southern Campaign
impact: Extended Gupta influence across Deccan through conquest and diplomacy
facts: Recorded in Allahabad Pillar Inscription

name: Allahabad Pillar Inscription
impact: Details his conquests, administration, and achievements
facts: Written by Harisena, his court poet

name: Reign of Chandragupta II (Vikramaditya)
impact: Peak of Gupta power and cultural prosperity
facts: Patronized Kalidasa and promoted Sanskrit literature

name: Defeat of the Shakas
parties: Chandragupta II vs Western Shaka Satraps
impact: Gupta Empire gained control of western India
facts: Led to flourishing trade through port cities like Bharuch

name: Visit of Chinese Monk Faxian
impact: Provided a detailed foreign account of Gupta society and Buddhism
facts: Noted the prosperity, justice system, and religious tolerance

name: Composition of Kalidasa’s Works
impact: Golden age of Sanskrit drama and poetry
facts: Works include Shakuntala, Meghaduta, and Raghuvamsha

name: Invasion of the Huna (White Huns)
impact: Marked the beginning of Gupta decline
facts: Skandagupta repelled the Hunas but drained the empire’s treasury

name: Death of Skandagupta
impact: End of effective Gupta resistance to foreign invasions
facts: Internal instability and succession crises followed

name: Fragmentation of Gupta Empire
impact: Gupta empire split into regional kingdoms, end of golden age
facts: Regional dynasties rose in Bengal and central India

name: Foundation of the Delhi Sultanate
impact: Established the Mamluk (Slave) Dynasty, first Islamic rule over North India
facts: Qutb Minar construction began under his rule

name: Construction of Qutb Minar Begins
impact: Symbol of early Indo-Islamic architecture
facts: Finished by Iltutmish after Aibak’s death

name: Reign of Razia Sultan
impact: First and only female ruler of the Delhi Sultanate
facts: Faced opposition from Turkish nobles

name: Battle of Amroha
impact: Successfully repelled Mongol invasions
facts: Alauddin Khilji’s general Malik Nayak led the victory

name: Market Reforms by Alauddin Khilji
impact: Price control and rationing introduced in Delhi
facts: Regulated supply of grains, cloth, and labor wages

name: Invasion of Devagiri
impact: Major victory in Deccan, laid foundation for southern expansion
facts: Later renamed Daulatabad by Muhammad bin Tughlaq

name: Transfer of Capital to Daulatabad
impact: Forced migration failed miserably, leading to unrest and decline
facts: Capital was shifted back to Delhi after public revolt

name: Timur’s Invasion of Delhi
impact: Delhi sacked, weakened Sultanate severely
facts: Thousands were massacred; Timur returned to Central Asia

name: Establishment of Sayyid Dynasty
impact: Attempt to restore stability post-Timur’s invasion
facts: Considered puppet rulers under Timur’s successors

name: Battle of Panipat (First Lodi defeat)
impact: End of Delhi Sultanate, beginning of Mughal Empire
facts: Babur used gunpowder and field artillery effectively

name: Battle of Panipat (First Mughal Victory)
impact: Marked the beginning of the Mughal Empire in India
facts: Babur used gunpowder and cannons effectively for the first time in Indian history

name: Battle of Khanwa
impact: Crushed Rajput resistance and consolidated Mughal control
facts: Rana Sanga was wounded and later poisoned by his nobles

name: Akbar Becomes Emperor
impact: Expanded Mughal rule across most of India
facts: Only 13 years old when he became emperor

name: Battle of Haldighati
impact: Though technically a Mughal victory, Pratap’s resistance became legendary
facts: Chetak, Pratap’s horse, is honored in Indian folklore

name: Din-i Ilahi Introduced
impact: Attempted to promote religious tolerance by blending elements of various faiths
facts: Only a few followers adopted this new faith

name: Jahangir's Reign Begins
impact: Focused on justice and arts; issued the 'Chain of Justice'
facts: Married to Mehr-un-Nissa, later known as Nur Jahan

name: Construction of Taj Mahal Begins
impact: Became one of the world’s most iconic monuments of love
facts: Built in memory of Mumtaz Mahal, took ~22 years to complete

name: Aurangzeb Becomes Emperor
impact: Expanded Mughal territory to its greatest extent but faced many revolts
facts: Imprisoned his father Shah Jahan in Agra Fort

name: Battle of Samugarh
impact: Aurangzeb secured succession by defeating his elder brother
facts: Dara Shikoh was later executed

name: Death of Aurangzeb
impact: Marked the beginning of the end of Mughal dominance
facts: Empire fragmented soon after his death

name: Battle of Plassey
parties: British East India Company vs Nawab Siraj-ud-Daulah
impact: Established British political control in Bengal
facts: Robert Clive bribed Mir Jafar to betray the Nawab

name: Battle of Buxar
parties: British vs Mughal Emperor Shah Alam II & Nawabs of Oudh and Bengal
impact: Consolidated British authority in eastern India
facts: Led to the Diwani rights (tax collection) being granted to British

name: Regulating Act Passed
impact: First step to bring East India Company under Parliament control
facts: Established the post of Governor-General of Bengal

name: Permanent Settlement Introduced
impact: Created a class of Zamindars who collected taxes
facts: Led to peasant exploitation and rural distress

name: First War of Indian Independence
parties: Indian soldiers vs British East India Company
impact: Ended Company rule, led to direct Crown control
facts: Also called Sepoy Mutiny or Revolt of 1857

name: Government of India Act 1858
impact: Transferred governance from East India Company to the Crown
facts: Queen Victoria promised non-interference in religious matters

name: Formation of Indian National Congress
impact: Became the main platform for Indian nationalism
facts: Founded by A.O. Hume, a retired British officer

name: Partition of Bengal
impact: Led to mass protests and Swadeshi movement
facts: Revoked in 1911 due to public backlash

name: Jallianwala Bagh Massacre
impact: Horrified Indians and intensified the freedom struggle
facts: Over 1,000 unarmed civilians were killed

name: Simon Commission Arrives
impact: All Indian political parties boycotted it
facts: Slogan: 'Simon Go Back!' became nationwide cry

name: Government of India Act 1935
impact: Introduced provincial autonomy and federal structure
facts: Served as a basis for India’s future constitution

name: Quit India Movement
impact: Demanded an end to British rule during WWII
facts: Gandhi gave the slogan: 'Do or Die'

name: Mountbatten Plan Announced
impact: Proposed partition of India and independence
facts: Led to creation of India and Pakistan

impact: Established British political control in Bengal
facts: Robert Clive bribed Mir Jafar to betray the Nawab
